awd_titl_txt: GOALI:A Study of Point Defects in Thick, Free-Standing Acceptor-Doped GaN
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical description: Semiconductors are a class of materials that has enabled the development of most modern electronics including tablets, cell phones, and medical diagnostic equipment. Gallium nitride, the semiconductor studied in this project, was the focus of the 2014 Nobel Prize in Physics because its special material properties made possible the energy efficient LED lighting now familiar to many homeowners.  Surprisingly, material and structural imperfections are a necessary part of the successful application of this semiconductor. For this reason, the present research project investigates the properties of a certain class of imperfections that act as traps for electrons. Both fundamental and practical information are determined from the electronic and structural studies.  In addition to the basic educational benefits afforded students working on this technologically significant issue, students gain first-hand knowledge and learn about potential advances from industrial personnel who actively grow the materials and devices.

Technical description: The project is designed to better understand the acceptor impurities in GaN by microscopically investigating their structure and charge state. The specific focus is electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) measurements of mm-thick free-standing crystals of GaN doped with technologically important acceptors such as magnesium and carbon. Until recently, EPR of GaN has been hampered by the limited total number of defects and non-uniform strain inherent to thin films. The availability of thick free-standing GaN crystals increases the number of detectable centers and minimizes strain, thus enabling the study of characteristics uniquely addressed by EPR, such as charge state and local structure. In addition, the potential influence of the defects on device properties is investigated with the help of a GOALI partner, Kyma Tech.  The study provides previously unavailable fundamental properties such as defect symmetry, and the determination of practical information such as association of a specific defect with an energy level.  Overall, the results enhance the understanding of the role of point defects in both bulk and thin film acceptor-doped GaN.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit Outcomes -  The Mg-acceptor in GaN, which is critical to the production of white-light LEDs, is affected by the presence of strain that can change the effectiveness of the impurity.  We demonstrated the effects of strain using magnetic resonance spectroscopy and found that the strain varies with thickness and doping concentration. 

Be and C are also important impurities in GaN.   They capture stray electrons that are unintentionally added during growth and therefore create insulating material. The insulating form is needed to produce high power devices such as those to be placed in car engines or airplanes.  These GaN-based power devices minimize the number of components required for operation and therefore improve the energy efficiency.  Our work revealed how the impurities change GaN from being conducting to insulating.  We showed that after capturing the electrons during growth, there is not enough energy in the system to re-release the trapped carriers. Therefore, doping with carbon transforms the as-grown slightly conducting material into insulating GaN.

 

Broader Impacts – During the course of this award, students were able to interact with scientists and engineers in a variety of disciplines such as materials growth and device manufacturing.  Through them, the practical utility of their work became clear:  the understanding of basic mechanisms gleaned from their studies enables the production of functional, energy efficient products.  The students discussed their work with scientists at local meetings in the southeast, national meetings throughout the US, as well as one international conference in Japan. Two of the graduate students working on these projects received their Ph.D.’s during the course of this award.  One is using his knowledge of magnetic resonance to design imaging systems for medical diagnostics.
